headline.print_headline: Salads or No, Cheap Burgers Revive McDonald's
headline.main: Salads or No, Cheap Burgers Revive McDonald's

docs.lead_paragraph: The turnaround has come not from greater sales of healthy foods but from selling more fast-food basics.
docs.snippet: The turnaround has come not from greater sales of healthy foods but from selling more fast-food basics.

docs.abstract: Letter from Susan Neely of American Beverage Assn says industry is making wider range of beverages available in schools and limiting soft drinks sold in high school vending machines
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Hazardous to Your Health'' (column, April 11), Nicholas D. Kristof discusses soft drinks in relation to the complex problem of obesity. The beverage industry is doing its part to help. We've made a wider range of beverages available to school students over the past decade, including bottled water, 100 percent juice, sports drinks, diet drinks and low-fat milk products.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     In ''Hazardous to Your Health'' (column, April 11), Nicholas D. Kristof discusses soft drinks in relation to the complex problem of obesity.      The beverage industry is doing its part to help. We've made a wider range of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks Rise as Federal Reserve Suggests That It May Stop Increasing Interest Rates The Federal Reserve hinted that it might stop its campaign to raise interest rates as early as next month. According to a summary released yesterday of the Fed's policy meeting in late March, ''most members thought that the end of the tightening process was likely to be near, and some expressed concerns about the dangers of tightening too much.'' [Page C1.] Stocks rallied after the Federal Reserve minutes suggested that its 21-month-old policy of higher interest rates might be coming to an end. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 22.32 points, to 1,307.65. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 194.99 points, to 11,268.77. The Nasdaq composite index increased 44.98 points, to 2,356.14. All three indexes had their biggest increase since April 21 of last year. [C8.] McDonald's Dollar Menu Raises Sales and Concerns The enormous success of the McDonald's Dollar Menu has helped stimulate positive comparable-store sales growth at the company for 36 consecutive months. In three years, McDonald's revenues have increased 33 percent and its shares have rocketed 170 percent, a remarkable turnaround for a company that only four years ago seemed to be going nowhere. But there may be a hidden cost. McDonald's has marketed the Dollar Menu -- which includes double cheeseburgers, the fried McChicken sandwich and French fries among its choices-- to teenagers, young adults and minority groups that are already plagued with an especially high incidence of obesity and related health problems like diabetes. [A1.] In Detroit, a Rush to the Doctor's Office The auto industry's efforts to rein in employee health costs is causing an expensive backlash, as union workers and their spouses hurry to Michigan doctors for knee replacements and other elective procedures before they lose their comprehensive medical benefits. [C1.] Consciously or not, the tens of thousands of General Motors workers who face decisions about the company's buyout offers before an early June deadline are getting a crash course in medical cost-benefit analysis. [C1.] Bush Names Portman to Be Budget Director President Bush continued the gradual overhaul of his staff, turning to another trusted insider, Rob Portman, the United States trade representative, to be budget director. [A18.] Freddie Mac to Pay $3.8 Million Over Fund-Raising Freddie Mac, the home mortgage giant, agreed to pay $3.8 million in penalties to the Federal Election Commission, which had accused it of improperly funneling corporate executives' donations to candidates and holding fund-raisers that often benefited lawmakers on an influential House panel. [A15.] Same Famous Face to Promote Firm After Merger Sam Waterston, the ''Law & Order'' actor who served for two years as the spokesman for the TD Waterhouse brokerage firm, is becoming the face and voice of TD Ameritrade. The Ameritrade Holding Corporation, which operated the Ameritrade brokerage, completed the acquisition of TD Waterhouse USA in January. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.] UnitedHealth Chief Seeks to Limit Stock Options William W. McGuire, the chief executive of the UnitedHealth Group, said that he had asked his board to stop awarding stock options to senior executives. The company also said that its profit in the first quarter rose 21 percent. [C9.] I.B.M. Profit Rises as International Sales Increase I.B.M. reported a solid gain in quarterly profit, helped by continued improvement in its services business, cost-cutting and rising sales of chips to videogame makers. Revenue for the company, the largest computer technology supplier, met the expectations of Wall Street analysts but was flat from the quarter a year earlier. First-quarter revenues rose 61 percent in India and 15 percent in China. ''We'll continue to shift investments to these high-growth countries,'' said the company's chief financial officer, Mark Loughridge, above. Indeed, I.B.M. said it would hold its yearly conference for financial analysts, which is traditionally in New York, in Bangalore, India. [C3.] Yahoo reported a 22 percent decline in quarterly profit but met Wall Street's earnings forecast, helped by solid growth in advertising sales. [C1.] Texas Instruments, the maker of chips for mobile phones, said that its first-quarter profit rose 42 percent as sales surged in India and China. [C9.] Boston Scientific, which expects to complete its acquisition of Guidant shortly, said that its first-quarter earnings fell 7.3 percent on slower sales of devices used to treat clogged arteries. [C6.] Merrill Lynch reported robust first-quarter earnings, with stronger-than-expected trading results that brought it closer in line with peers like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. [C3.] Debate on Investment Banks' Private Equity Spending Several unsolicited takeover attempts in Britain by the private equity funds of Goldman Sachs have reignited talk in London and on Wall Street about the often complicated role of investment banks in private equity. [C6.] Russian Oil Company Approves Plan to Consolidate The Russian state oil company Rosneft approved a plan to streamline its units into a single company centered on assets acquired from Yukos. The move opens the way for one of the largest-ever initial public offerings. [C6.] Marie Claire Magazine Appoints an Editor Marie Claire magazine is getting a face lift, replacing its editor in chief, Lesley Jane Seymour, with Joanna Coles, the executive editor of More. [C9.]

headline.print_headline: Research Ties Lack of Sleep To Risk for Hypertension
headline.main: Research Ties Lack of Sleep to Risk for Hypertension

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study helps explain how extra hours spent awake can change the body.
docs.snippet: A new study helps explain how extra hours spent awake can change the body.

headline.main: Research Ties Lack of Sleep To Risk for Hypertension

docs.abstract: Dr James E Gangwisch, Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health postdoctoral fellow, leads study that suggests people who do not get adequate sleep may be more likely to develop high blood pressure; research is published in journal Hypertension (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Getting too little sleep may be a significant risk factor for high blood pressure. In a study of more than 4,800 men and women, people ages 32 to 59 who got five hours of sleep a night or less were about 60 percent more likely to develop hypertension than those who slept six to eight hours.
docs.snippet: Getting too little sleep may be a significant risk factor for high blood pressure.     In a study of more than 4,800 men and women, people ages 32 to 59 who got five hours of sleep a night or less were about 60 percent more likely to develop...

headline.main: Common Genetic Link to Obesity Is Discovered

docs.abstract: Dr Michael F Christman of Boston University leads study that identifies genetic variation that predisposes people to obesity; research used data from Framingham Heart Study and is published in journal Science; other genetic links to obesity have been established; this variant, however, is much more common in general population than other genes previously identified (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A genetic variation predisposing people to obesity has been detected by a team of researchers at Boston University and elsewhere. Though the gene is expected to be just one of the many that contribute to the disease, its detection raises hopes that the others may be discovered within the next five years or so, said Michael F. Christman, a leader of the team. Although several obesity-related genes are already known, they affect specific families and are very rare in the general population. The new genetic variant is common, occurring in 10 percent of European and African-American populations. ''We think this will be the first of many common variants that cause obesity,'' said Alan Herbert, another leader. The finding is reported in the current issue of the journal Science.
docs.snippet: A genetic variation predisposing people to obesity has been detected by a team of researchers at Boston University and elsewhere. Though the gene is expected to be just one of the many that contribute to the disease, its detection raises hopes that...

headline.main: Mayor Seeks to Lower a Barrier for Food Stamps

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration, in a significant departure from the welfare policies of the Giuliani era, is pursuing a federal waiver that would make it easier for able-bodied adults who do not have children to qualify for food stamps, even if they are not working. In his first term, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg hewed closely to the groundbreaking changes in welfare policy begun under his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who criticized what he called a culture of dependence on public aid and whose reforms were emulated in other large cities. But now Mr. Bloomberg is moving to loosen a major provision of welfare reform.
docs.snippet: New York City is trying to make it easier for adults without children to qualify for aid, even if they are not working.
